content: Regulation is a fundamental government function, with federal agencies issuing thousands of rules annually on various topics. The costs of complying with these regulations are not included in the federal budget process, prompting interest in measuring total regulatory costs and benefits. Efforts such as the Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis Creation and Sunset and Review Act of 2011 aim to assess these costs and benefits, although it is challenging to accurately measure them. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) has been required by Congress for nearly 14 years to prepare an annual report on the costs and benefits of federal rules. However, accurately measuring total regulatory costs and benefits is challenging due to difficulties in determining baselines and aggregating results from studies with different methodologies. Some doubt the possibility of an accurate measure. In September 2010, the Small Business Administration (SBA) released a report stating that the annual cost of federal regulations in 2008 was about $1.75 trillion. The report on "The Impact of Regulatory Costs on Small Firms" in 2010 stated that federal regulations cost about $1.75 trillion in 2008. Previous reports estimated costs between $416 billion and $1.1 trillion in different years. The $1.75 trillion estimate has been widely cited but criticized for overstating total costs. The report examines how the estimate was developed and compares it to previous estimates.
